trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Get a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage the Azure Batch service
trans-unit.target: Get a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage the Azure Batch service

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell cmdlets

trans-unit.source: This is a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage your Batch accounts and work with your Batch resources such as pools, jobs, and tasks.
trans-unit.target: This is a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage your Batch accounts and work with your Batch resources such as pools, jobs, and tasks.

trans-unit.source: You can perform many of the same tasks with Batch cmdlets that you carry out with the Batch APIs and the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can perform many of the same tasks with Batch cmdlets that you carry out with the Batch APIs and the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: This article is based on cmdlets in Azure PowerShell version 1.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: This article is based on cmdlets in Azure PowerShell version 1.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of Batch cmdlets and detailed cmdlet syntax, see the [Azure Batch cmdlet reference](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt125957.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of Batch cmdlets and detailed cmdlet syntax, see the [Azure Batch cmdlet reference](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt125957.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: **Azure PowerShell** - See [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions to download and install Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: **Azure PowerShell** - See [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions to download and install Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Because the Azure Batch cmdlets ship in the Azure Resource Manager module, you'll need to run the **Login-AzureRmAccount** cmdlet to connect to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Because the Azure Batch cmdlets ship in the Azure Resource Manager module, you'll need to run the **Login-AzureRmAccount** cmdlet to connect to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: More details are in [Azure PowerShell 1.0](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/azps-1-0/).
trans-unit.target: More details are in [Azure PowerShell 1.0](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/azps-1-0/).

trans-unit.source: **Register with the Batch provider namespace (one-time operation)** - Before working with your Batch accounts, you have to register with the Batch provider namespace.
trans-unit.target: **Register with the Batch provider namespace (one-time operation)** - Before working with your Batch accounts, you have to register with the Batch provider namespace.

trans-unit.source: This operation only needs to be performed once per subscription.
trans-unit.target: This operation only needs to be performed once per subscription.

trans-unit.source: Manage Batch accounts and keys
trans-unit.target: Manage Batch accounts and keys

trans-unit.source: Create a Batch account
trans-unit.target: Create a Batch account

trans-unit.source: **New-AzureRmBatchAccount** creates a new Batch account in a specified resource group.
trans-unit.target: **New-AzureRmBatchAccount** creates a new Batch account in a specified resource group.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have a resource group, create one by running the [New-AzureRmResourceGroup](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt603739.aspx) cmdlet, specifying one of the Azure regions in the **Location** parameter, such as "Central US".
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have a resource group, create one by running the [New-AzureRmResourceGroup](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt603739.aspx) cmdlet, specifying one of the Azure regions in the **Location** parameter, such as "Central US".

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Then, create a new Batch account account in the resource group, also specifying an account name for <*account_name*> and a location where the Batch service is available.
trans-unit.target: Then, create a new Batch account account in the resource group, also specifying an account name for <*account_name*> and a location where the Batch service is available.

trans-unit.source: Creating the account can take several minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: Creating the account can take several minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The Batch account name must be unique to Azure, contain between 3 and 24 characters, and use lowercase letters and numbers only.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The Batch account name must be unique to Azure, contain between 3 and 24 characters, and use lowercase letters and numbers only.

trans-unit.source: Get account access keys
trans-unit.target: Get account access keys

trans-unit.source: **Get-AzureRmBatchAccountKeys** shows the access keys associated with an Azure Batch account.
trans-unit.target: **Get-AzureRmBatchAccountKeys** shows the access keys associated with an Azure Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example, run the following to get the primary and secondary keys of the account you created.
trans-unit.target: For example, run the following to get the primary and secondary keys of the account you created.

trans-unit.source: Generate a new access key
trans-unit.target: Generate a new access key

trans-unit.source: **New-AzureRmBatchAccountKey** generates a new primary or secondary account key for an Azure Batch account.
trans-unit.target: **New-AzureRmBatchAccountKey** generates a new primary or secondary account key for an Azure Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example, to generate a new primary key for your Batch account, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, to generate a new primary key for your Batch account, type:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To generate a new secondary key, specify "Secondary" for the **KeyType** parameter.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To generate a new secondary key, specify "Secondary" for the **KeyType** parameter.

trans-unit.source: You have to regenerate the primary and secondary keys separately.
trans-unit.target: You have to regenerate the primary and secondary keys separately.

trans-unit.source: Delete a Batch account
trans-unit.target: Delete a Batch account

trans-unit.source: **Remove-AzureRmBatchAccount** deletes a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: **Remove-AzureRmBatchAccount** deletes a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, confirm you want to remove the account.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, confirm you want to remove the account.

trans-unit.source: Account removal can take some time to complete.
trans-unit.target: Account removal can take some time to complete.

trans-unit.source: Create a BatchAccountContext object
trans-unit.target: Create a BatchAccountContext object

trans-unit.source: To create and manage pools, jobs, tasks, and other resources in a Batch account, you first need to create a BatchAccountContext object to store your account name and keys:
trans-unit.target: To create and manage pools, jobs, tasks, and other resources in a Batch account, you first need to create a BatchAccountContext object to store your account name and keys:

trans-unit.source: You pass this context into cmdlets that interact with the Batch service by using the **BatchContext** parameter.
trans-unit.target: You pass this context into cmdlets that interact with the Batch service by using the **BatchContext** parameter.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the account's primary key is used for authentication, but you can explicitly select the key to use by changing your BatchAccountContext object’s **KeyInUse** property: `$context.KeyInUse = "Secondary"`.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the account's primary key is used for authentication, but you can explicitly select the key to use by changing your BatchAccountContext object’s **KeyInUse** property: `$context.KeyInUse = "Secondary"`.

trans-unit.source: Create and modify Batch resources
trans-unit.target: Create and modify Batch resources

trans-unit.source: Use cmdlets such as **New-AzureBatchPool**, **New-AzureBatchJob**, and **New-AzureBatchTask** to create resources under a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Use cmdlets such as **New-AzureBatchPool**, **New-AzureBatchJob**, and **New-AzureBatchTask** to create resources under a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: There are corresponding **Get-** and **Set-** cmdlets to update the properties of existing resources, and **Remove-** cmdlets to remove resources under a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: There are corresponding **Get-** and **Set-** cmdlets to update the properties of existing resources, and **Remove-** cmdlets to remove resources under a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following cmdlet creates a new Batch pool configured to use size Small virtual machines imaged with the latest operating system version of family 3 (Windows Server 2012), with the target number of compute nodes determined by an autoscaling formula.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following cmdlet creates a new Batch pool configured to use size Small virtual machines imaged with the latest operating system version of family 3 (Windows Server 2012), with the target number of compute nodes determined by an autoscaling formula.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the formula is simply $TargetDedicated=3, indicating the number of compute nodes in the pool is 3 at most.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the formula is simply $TargetDedicated=3, indicating the number of compute nodes in the pool is 3 at most.

trans-unit.source: The **BatchContext** parameter specifies a previously defined variable *$context* as the BatchAccountContext object.
trans-unit.target: The **BatchContext** parameter specifies a previously defined variable *$context* as the BatchAccountContext object.

trans-unit.source: Query for pool, jobs, tasks, and other details
trans-unit.target: Query for pool, jobs, tasks, and other details

trans-unit.source: Use cmdlets such as **Get-AzureBatchPool** , **Get-AzureBatchJob**, and **Get-AzureBatchTask** to query for entities created under a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Use cmdlets such as **Get-AzureBatchPool** , **Get-AzureBatchJob**, and **Get-AzureBatchTask** to query for entities created under a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: Query for data
trans-unit.target: Query for data

trans-unit.source: As an example, use **Get-AzureBatchPools** to find your pools.
trans-unit.target: As an example, use **Get-AzureBatchPools** to find your pools.

trans-unit.source: By default this queries for all pools under your account, assuming you already stored the BatchAccountContext object in *$context*:
trans-unit.target: By default this queries for all pools under your account, assuming you already stored the BatchAccountContext object in *$context*:

trans-unit.source: Use an OData filter
trans-unit.target: Use an OData filter

trans-unit.source: You can supply an OData filter using the **Filter** parameter to find only the objects you’re interested in.
trans-unit.target: You can supply an OData filter using the **Filter** parameter to find only the objects you’re interested in.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can find all pools with ids starting with “myPool”:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can find all pools with ids starting with “myPool”:

trans-unit.source: This method is not as flexible as using “Where-Object” in a local pipeline.
trans-unit.target: This method is not as flexible as using “Where-Object” in a local pipeline.

trans-unit.source: However, the query gets sent to the Batch service directly so that all filtering happens on the server side, saving Internet bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: However, the query gets sent to the Batch service directly so that all filtering happens on the server side, saving Internet bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: Use the Id parameter
trans-unit.target: Use the Id parameter

trans-unit.source: An alternative to an OData filter is to use the **Id** parameter.
trans-unit.target: An alternative to an OData filter is to use the **Id** parameter.

trans-unit.source: To query for a specific pool with id "myPool":
trans-unit.target: To query for a specific pool with id "myPool":

trans-unit.source: The **Id** parameter supports only full-id search, not wildcards or OData-style filters.
trans-unit.target: The **Id** parameter supports only full-id search, not wildcards or OData-style filters.

trans-unit.source: Use the MaxCount parameter
trans-unit.target: Use the MaxCount parameter

trans-unit.source: By default, each cmdlet returns a maximum of 1000 objects.
trans-unit.target: By default, each cmdlet returns a maximum of 1000 objects.

trans-unit.source: If you reach this limit, either refine your filter to bring back fewer objects, or explicitly set a maximum using the **MaxCount** parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you reach this limit, either refine your filter to bring back fewer objects, or explicitly set a maximum using the **MaxCount** parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: To remove the upper bound, set **MaxCount** to 0 or less.
trans-unit.target: To remove the upper bound, set **MaxCount** to 0 or less.

trans-unit.source: Use the pipeline
trans-unit.target: Use the pipeline

trans-unit.source: Batch cmdlets can leverage the PowerShell pipeline to send data between cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Batch cmdlets can leverage the PowerShell pipeline to send data between cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: This has the same effect as specifying a parameter but makes listing multiple entities easier.
trans-unit.target: This has the same effect as specifying a parameter but makes listing multiple entities easier.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following finds all tasks under your account:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following finds all tasks under your account:
